article.headline: Philip Morris says cigarette sales in many places could end in a decade and theyâve got a âsaferâ product to replace them
article.body: Philip Morris International Inc. thinks the sale of cigarettes could come to an end in countries around the world in the coming years, but have no fear, because theyâve got another product ready to sell that offers a âsaferâ nicotine fix. Philip Morris PM, +0.70% Â and the Food and Drug Administration announced this week that the companyâs IQOS âelectrically heated tobacco systemâ has been given the green light to market as a safer alternative to cigarettes. Now designated as a âmodified riskâ product, the company can promote these items âas containing a reduced level of or presenting a reduced exposure to a substance,â according to the FDA statement. A spokesperson for Philip Morris says the product wonât be marketed as safer than cigarettes, but rather focus on the âmodified riskâ language authorized by the FDA. Philip Morris, the company behind Marlboro cigarettes, describes these alternative products as heating rather than burning tobacco, which a cigarette does. Burning tobacco, which reaches 600 degrees Celsius, âcontains high levels of harmful chemicals,â according to the companyâs website. The tobacco heating system (THS) heats tobacco to 350 degrees Celsius. Philip Morris has turned its focus to the IQOS product, with Philip Morrisâ Chief Operating Officer Jacek Olczak saying at the Deutsche Bank dbAccess Global Consumer Conference last month that the company is committed to âworking towards realizing [the] potential of this opportunity,â according to a FactSet transcript. The development comes at a time when Philip Morris is preparing for the end of cigarette sales. âI am convinced that it is possible to completely end cigarette sales in many countries within 10 to 15 years, but for that to happen, manufacturers and governments need to work in the same direction,â said AndrÃ© Calantzopoulos, chief executive of Philip Morris, in a letter to stakeholders published with the companyâs report on its environmental, social and governance (ESG) efforts. Calantzopoulos notes the âskeptical stakeholdersâ like international organizations and the media that âdoubt that harm reduction through smoke-free alternatives is sound public health policy or argue that our purpose-driven strategy is nothing more than window dressing.â He highlights other areas where advice to reduce a hazardous activity is accepted, such as lowering sugar intake for better health. âI feel strongly that people who smoke cigarettes, the most harmful nicotine-containing product, should not be denied the opportunity to switch to better alternatives,â Calantzopoulos wrote. In 2019, Philip Morris sold 706.7 billion cigarettes, down 4.5% from 2018, according to a June CFRA report. Over the next few years, CFRA forecasts that cigarette consumption will fall 3% each year. Shipments of heated tobacco products, on the other hand, soared 44.2% to 59.7 billion units in 2019. This is a good thing for Philip Morris âgiven heightened regulatory and legal headwinds surrounding e-cigarettes in the U.S., as Philip Morrisâ IQOS product underwent a lengthy FDA review process before getting the green light for sale in the U.S. in April 2019,â CFRA said. CFRA rates Philip Morris stock buy with a 12-month price target of $95. âDespite declining cigarette consumption in developed markets, we look for pricing gains and growth in emerging markets to support revenues,â CFRA said. âWe think the launch of Philip Morrisâ heated tobacco product, IQOS, will lead to market share gains and help offset cigarette volume weakness.â The company reported earnings and revenue that beat expectations in the most recent quarter. The stock is down 14.3% for the year to date while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% Â has fallen 8.6% for the period. Philip Morrisâ goal now is to move into a âsmoke-free future,â said Huub Savelkouls, the companyâs chief sustainability officer, in a post on LinkedIn. Philip Morris has cut its cigarette portfolio by more than 700 SKUs (stock-keeping units) over the last four years and aims to move 40 million smokers of its cigarettes over to smoke-free products. Savelkouls says engagement, including between the company and the investment community, is needed to achieve change. âMaking cigarettes obsolete can be achieved much more rapidly through inclusivity and openness,â Savelkouls wrote. âOur goals are really not that different and that is where the potential for creating impactful change lies: working together towards making the world smoke-free.â
